Tag proposal: typesetting
description:
For stories relating to: how text is laid out an

Discussion: should it include e.g. stories about Pango? Unicode (partially relevant to typesetting/typography I suppose)? These are a bit further from "typsetting" but is relevant to typography and encoding? Should it include stories about markup languages?

See searches for e.g. LaTeX, Typst, typography, PostScript, Pandoc, etc. and some misc stories like Let's write a PDF file.

I wouldn't be the one filtering things out, but I could see how to some people, the way text is presented on paper/screens might not be that interesting compared to more typical programming/computing topics.

I think if we figure out the scope properly it shouldn't be much additional complexity.

I'm not familiar with the tag-submission process so please correct me if there's anything I'm missing!
description_plain:
For stories relating to: how text is laid out an

Discussion: should it include e.g. stories about [Pango](https://lobste.rs/search?q=pango&what=stories&order=relevance)? [Unicode](https://lobste.rs/search?q=unicode&what=stories&order=relevance) (partially relevant to typesetting/typography I suppose)? These are a bit further from "typsetting" but is relevant to typography and encoding? Should it include stories about markup languages?

See searches for e.g. [LaTeX](https://lobste.rs/search?q=latex&what=stories&order=relevance), [Typst](https://lobste.rs/search?q=typst&what=stories&order=relevance), [typography](https://lobste.rs/search?q=typography&what=stories&order=relevance), [PostScript](https://lobste.rs/search?q=postscript&what=stories&order=relevance), [Pandoc](https://lobste.rs/search?q=pandoc&what=stories&order=relevance), etc. and some misc stories like [Let's write a PDF file](https://lobste.rs/s/3fxml1/let_s_write_pdf_file_2015).

I wouldn't be the one filtering things out, but I could see how to some people, the way text is presented on paper/screens might not be that interesting compared to more typical programming/computing topics.

I think if we figure out the scope properly it shouldn't be much additional complexity.

I'm not familiar with the tag-submission process so please correct me if there's anything I'm missing!

What are you reading this week?
description:
Also what were you reading? What are you planning to read next?

I've finished Darwin's "The Voyage of the Beagle" and it's really good. Rereading The Mikado Method left me with same opinion the it's great technique badly described.

My next big book is The Memory Code by Lynne Kelly. My next big "computer" book is The Powerful Python by Aaron Maxwell (I hope it will make me less of quickly-let's-get-the-shit-together and more of quickly-let's-get-the-shit-right).
description_plain:
Also what were you reading? What are you planning to read next?

I've finished Darwin's "The Voyage of the Beagle" and it's really good. Rereading The Mikado Method left me with same opinion the it's great technique badly described.

My next big book is The Memory Code by Lynne Kelly. My next big "computer" book is The Powerful Python by Aaron Maxwell (I hope it will make me less of quickly-let's-get-the-shit-together and more of quickly-let's-get-the-shit-right).

title: Property-Based Testing in Practice
description: Property-based testing (PBT) is a testing methodology where users write executable formal specifications of software components and an automated harness checks these specifications against many automatically generated inputs. From its roots in the QuickCheck library in Haskell, PBT has made significant inroads in mainstream languages and industrial practice at companies such as Amazon, Volvo, and Stripe. As PBT extends its reach, it is important to understand how developers are using it in practice, where they see its strengths and weaknesses, and what innovations are needed to make it more effective.
description_plain:
Property-based testing (PBT) is a testing methodology where users
write executable formal specifications of software components and
an automated harness checks these specifications against many
automatically generated inputs. From its roots in the QuickCheck
library in Haskell, PBT has made significant inroads in mainstream
languages and industrial practice at companies such as Amazon,
Volvo, and Stripe. As PBT extends its reach, it is important to understand 
how developers are using it in practice, where they see
its strengths and weaknesses, and what innovations are needed to
make it more effective.
